quiz.question: Geometric transformations include translation, rotation, scaling, reflection, and shearing.
2D translation can be represented as a 2×2 matrix without homogeneous coordinates.
Homogeneous coordinates allow translation to be represented as a linear transformation using a 3×3 matrix.
Two successive rotations are additive; the total rotation is the sum of the individual rotation angles.
Two successive scalings are additive; the total scaling factor is the sum of the individual scaling factors.
Matrix multiplication is commutative for transformation matrices.
The inverse of a rotation by angle θ is a rotation by angle -θ.
To rotate an object around a fixed point, you must first translate the fixed point to the origin.
Reflection about the x-axis can be represented by the matrix [[1,0],[0,-1]].
Shearing is a transformation that preserves the area of an object.
In 3D, rotation around the z-axis does not affect the z-coordinate of points.
The order of applying 3D rotations does not affect the final orientation of an object.
Reflection relative to the xy-plane in 3D changes the sign of the z-coordinate.
A 3D scaling transformation about a fixed point requires translating the fixed point to the origin first.
quiz.section: 3D SCALING ABOUT A FIXED POINT (X_F, Y_F, Z_F)

quiz.question: The inverse of a translation by (tx, ty) is a translation by (-tx, -ty).
A 2D rotation matrix is always orthogonal.
The transformation matrix for scaling by (2, 2) is the same as the matrix for uniform scaling by 2.
In homogeneous coordinates, the point (x, y, 0) represents a point at infinity.
Shearing along the x-axis changes the y-coordinate based on the x-coordinate.
Two successive translations are multiplicative.
The determinant of a rotation matrix is always 1.
Reflection about the line y = x can be represented by swapping x and y coordinates.
In 3D, rotation around the y-axis uses a different rotation matrix structure than rotation around the x-axis.
The identity matrix represents a transformation that leaves all points unchanged.
A 3D translation matrix in homogeneous coordinates is a 4×4 matrix.
Scaling by a factor of zero reduces an object to a single point.
Inverse scaling by (sx, sy) is scaling by (1/sx, 1/sy).
Shearing transformation is also known as skew transformation.
A 2D transformation matrix must be square to be invertible.
Rotation in 3D around an arbitrary axis can be decomposed into rotations around the coordinate axes.
Reflection about the origin in 2D is equivalent to a 180-degree rotation.
A translation matrix does not have an inverse if the translation vector is zero.
The transformation matrices for 2D and 3D rotations are always symmetric.
In homogeneous coordinates, the third coordinate must always be 1 for representing finite points.
A shear transformation can be represented by a matrix with ones on the diagonal and zeros elsewhere.
Combining a rotation and a translation in 2D can be done with a single 3×3 matrix using homogeneous coordinates.
3D reflection about the yz-plane changes the sign of the x-coordinate.
The inverse of a combined transformation M1 * M2 is M2⁻¹ * M1⁻¹.
Scaling with negative factors results in reflection as well as resizing.
In 3D, a rotation of 90 degrees around the x-axis followed by a rotation of 90 degrees around the y-axis yields the same result as the reverse order.
The transformation matrix for a 2D rotation is [[cosθ, -sinθ], [sinθ, cosθ]].
A point at the origin is unaffected by a rotation transformation.
Shearing preserves parallel lines in the object.
In 3D, a translation along the z-axis only affects the z-coordinate.
A reflection transformation is its own inverse.
The composition of a scaling and a rotation is commutative.
A 3D rotation matrix has a determinant of -1.
Homogeneous coordinates allow representing points at infinity with w = 0.
